sn56.52:1.1: “Mendicants, suppose there was a lotus pond that was fifty leagues long, fifty leagues wide, and fifty leagues deep, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
sn56.52:1.2: Then a person would pick up some water on the tip of a blade of grass.
sn56.52:1.4: Which is more: the water on the tip of the blade of grass, or the water in the lotus pond?”
sn56.52:1.5: “Sir, the water in the lotus pond is certainly more. The water on the tip of a blade of grass is tiny.
sn56.52:1.6: Compared to the water in the lotus pond, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction.”
sn56.52:1.7: “In the same way, for a noble disciple …
sn56.52:1.8: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
